I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
programmatic approach for the Third Financial Sector Program and (ii) a proposed policy-based 
loan to the Kingdom of Cambodia for subprogram 1 of the Third Financial Sector Program. The 
report describes proposed Implementing subprogram 2 of the Third Financial Sector Program 
technical assistance (TA), and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the 
authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA.1 
 
2.  The development framework for Cambodia’s finance sector is based on a 10-year rolling 
finance sector development strategy (FSDS) of the government. The 10-year strategy was 
recently updated  as the FSDS, 2011–2020.2  It is aligned with Cambodia’s updated National 
Strategy and Development Plan, 2009–2013 and Rectangular Strategy, as well as with the 
country  strategy  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  for  Cambodia,  2011–2013.  It  has 
incorporated the recommendations of the Financial Sector Assessment Program, 2010 of the 
International  Monetary  Fund  and  the  World  Bank.  Bilateral  meetings  were  held  with  key 
stakeholders and were followed by several workshops with government agencies. Development 
partner coordination was further strengthened during the update of the FSDS. ADB meets 
regularly with all development partners in the finance sector to discuss current issues and 
coordinate activities. This informal group of development partners periodically discusses finance 
issues with relevant business associations and Cambodia’s Private Sector Forum. As per the 
Government  of  Cambodia’s  request,  the  proposed  third  program  is  a  cluster  of  three 
subprograms to implement the first phase of the FSDS, 2011–2020. These reforms have been 
discussed  with  all  relevant  government  agencies,  industry  associations,  and  development 
partners. 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
3.  A robust finance sector is essential for sustainable economic growth. Cambodia’s real 
gross domestic product (GDP) grew strongly at 9.1% per year on average from 1998 to 2008. 
This slowed in 2009 and 2010 because of indirect effects of the recent global economic crisis. 
The authorities nevertheless aim to pursue economic reform that will return the economy to pre-
crisis growth rates. The period of robust economic performance was led by the private sector, in 
particular  garments,  tourist-related  services,  construction,  and  agriculture.  A  substantial 
proportion of these activities  were financed by foreign direct investment and the domestic 
finance system. With a rapidly growing commercial economy that requires a sound finance 
system to sustain growth, the government is committed to the long-term development of the 
finance sector, channeling financial resources to productive investments, and managing the 
inherent risks to achieve sustainable economic growth over the long term and contribute to 
poverty  reduction.  To  promote  sustainable  economic  growth,  reduce  poverty,  and  mitigate 
shocks emanating from external financial crises, ADB supports finance sector development in 
its developing member countries, including Cambodia. Since 2001, ADB has become the lead 
development partner supporting Cambodia’s finance sector. 
 
                                                
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  ADB provided project preparatory TA: ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance to the Kingdom of Cambodia for Preparing 
the Third Financial Sector Program Cluster. Manila ( TA 7520-CAM).

2 
4.  ADB and the government began in 1999 their partnership to develop Cambodia’s then-
nascent finance sector. External assistance was sorely needed both to lay the groundwork for 
finance sector development and to rebuild capacity largely decimated during the conflict years. 
Fully cognizant of the pivotal role the sector would play in achieving economic transformation, 
and faced with a rapidly growing commercial economy potentially undermined by scarce capital, 
the government embarked on a long-term development strategy and plan for developing the 
country’s  finance  sector.  As  a  first  step,  and  with  ADB  assistance,  the  government 
commissioned the preparation of the FSDS, 2001–2010, which was to guide finance sector 
development during that period. To help implement the first phase of the FSDS, 2001–2010, 
ADB approved the $30 million first Financial Sector Program in November 2001.3 Implemented 
from 2001 to 2007, the first program enabled the government to begin establishing legal and 
regulatory  foundations,  consolidate  the  banking  system,  establish  key  regulatory  agencies, 
privatize state-owned banks and finance institutions, and commence the licensing of informal 
microfinance institutions (MFIs). 
 
5.  The FSDS, 2001–2010 was updated by the FSDS, 2006–2015 to take into account new 
challenges,  both  domestic  and  international,  as  well  as  market  developments.  The  FSDS, 
2006–2015 noted encouraging progress in sector development. Encouraging achievements 
under the first program prompted the government to request further support from ADB to 
continue its reform of the finance sector, and ADB approved the $45.3 million Second Financial 
Sector Program Cluster in December 2007.4 Implemented from 2007 to 2010, the second 
program completed reforms that helped boost confidence in the formal finance sector, advanced 
the legal and regulatory foundation, strengthened the capacity of regulatory agencies, and 
introduced part of the supporting infrastructure for financial activities. While Cambodia still has 
one of the lowest rates of financial intermediation in the world, it has improved since 2001 with 
the money supply growing from 13% of GDP in 2001 to 21% in 2006 and 40% in 2010. 
 
6.  As of the end of June 2011, the formal finance sector comprises the National Bank of 
Cambodia  (NBC),  29  commercial  banks,  6  specialized  financial  institutions,  and  2 
representative offices of foreign based banks; 26 licensed MFIs and 29 registered MFIs; 7 
insurance companies, 1 insurance broker, and 2 insurance agents; and the Securities and 
Exchange Commission of Cambodia (SECC) with 7 securities underwriters, 2 securities dealers, 
4 securities brokers, 2 investment advisers, and 3 cash settlement agents. On 11 July 2011, the 
government launched the Cambodian Securities Exchange, jointly owned by the Ministry of 
Economy and Finance (MEF) with 55% and the Korea Exchange with 45%, but trading has yet 
to commence. As in most developing countries, the banking system in Cambodia dominates the 
finance sector. Banking activities are not fully developed but are improving in rural areas, with 
MFIs providing most formal financial services. Microfinance is expanding rapidly, with total credit 
increasing  from  $35.0  million  in  2001  to  $514.4  million  in  June  2011  and  the  number  of 
borrowers increasing from 410,000 to 1.08 million over the same period. The Financial Industry 
Department in the MEF regulates and supervises the insurance subsector, which comprises six 
insurance companies and one re-insurer, the latter majority owned by the government. Growth 
has been steady with the premium total reaching $24.9 million in 2010, nearly seven times the 
$3.6 million in 2001.

7.  Achievements. Progress has been made on several fronts as positive and progressive 
reforms have been successfully implemented since 2001.5  Major highlights are6 
(i)  the enactment of key financial and commercial laws to support a sound and 
market-driven finance sector, 
(ii)  the rebuilding and strengthening of key financial institutions under the auspices 
of the NBC and the MEF, 
(iii)  the introduction of supporting financial infrastructure to enhance finance market 
activities and improve outreach to the rural poor, 
(iv)  the rebuilding of human capacity and technical know-how, and 
(v)  the finance sector’s growing role in mobilizing domestic financial resources to 
meet the demands of a growing economy. 
8.     Sector Challenges. Challenges to further developing the finance sector include low 
financial intermediation due to the rural and informal nature of the economy, vulnerability to 
external shocks due to a narrow economic base that is heavily dependent on international 
markets, governance issues as accounting and auditing practices are being further developed, 
and  inefficiencies due to a financial infrastructure that is not fully developed and corresponding 
technical capacity that is weak and needs to be further developed in line with the human 
capacity requirements of the sector. The third program will continue to address these challenges 
as outlined in the Outputs Section (paras 12-25 below). 
9.  Lessons. In moving to implement the FSDS, 2011–2020, past lessons clearly illustrate 
the following: (i) A set of long-term objectives is required to guide and shape medium-term 
policy design and implementation. (ii) Flexibility in design is important to accommodate changes 
in economic, social, and political circumstances. (iii) The time lag between the adoption of 
reforms and their effective enforcement needs to be shortened. (iv) Substantial TA resources 
are required to build technical capacity. (v) Maintaining monetary and financial stability are 
crucial to economic growth. (vi) Promoting good governance, under which financial growth and 
development is to be pursued, would anchor the FSDS. (vii) Enhancing the sector’s operational 
efficiency  would  facilitate  FSDS  implementation.  The  design  of  the  third  program  has 
incorporated these lessons. 
 
10.  Rebuilding Cambodia’s finance sector. This is a protracted process. While positive 
progress has been achieved, a large part of the country remains untapped by formal finance, 
as, at the end of 2010, less than 10% of the population had access to credit through the formal 
sector.  The  government  recognizes  that  attaining  inclusive  economic  growth  requires  a 
diversified,  competitive,  and  prudentially  sound  financial  system  to  ensure  that  financial 
resources are efficiently accumulated and effectively allocated. To implement the FSDS, 2011–
2020, the government requested ADB’s further support for its finance sector reforms under the 
third  program.  To  maintain  monetary  and  financial  stability,  the  third  program  will  actively 
promote the use of the local currency (the riel), update the core legal framework for banking and 
finance, enact additional commercial laws, and strengthen coordination among finance sector 
regulators. Support will be extended toward developing the recently launched securities market 
and operationalizing the money and interbank markets. Capacity building will continue in order 
to meet the increased demand for qualified staff for the growing number of financial institutions 
and their branch networks, as well as to enable existing regulators to shift from compliance- to 
risk-based  supervision.  Upgrading  supporting  infrastructure,  which  includes  accounting  and

auditing, anti-money laundering measures, and a payments system, is a long-term initiative that

B.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The expected impact of the third program is a sound, market-based finance sector able 
to enhance resource mobilization and support sustainable economic growth. The expected 
outcome is a growing, resilient, and efficient financial system. The third program comprises a 
series  of  three  single-tranche  subprograms  to  be  implemented  from  December  2010  to 
December 2013. Subprogram 1 has 20 reform actions, which the government implemented 
between December 2010 and October 2011. 
 
C.  Outputs 
12.  Third program policy measures include a set of sector reforms to improve the legal and 
regulatory framework and its application, strengthen institutional coordination among national 
regulatory agencies, promote confidence and growth in outreach, strengthen the application of 
supporting  infrastructure  and  international  standards,  develop  new  markets,  and  support 
capacity  development  more  sustainably.  The  program  has  four  outputs:  (i)  finance  sector 
stability maintained, (ii) confidence and financial intermediation improved, (iii) good governance 
promoted,  and  (iv)  finance  sector  efficiency  enhanced.  Key  activities  for  each  output  are 
described below. 
 
1.  Finance Sector Stability Maintained 
13.  Legal and regulatory framework for banks and microfinance institutions. As part of 
efforts to maintain financial stability, address the features of a fast-changing domestic market, 
and align it with the reality of closer international economic integration, the NBC is committed to 
updating the Law on the Organization and Conduct of the NBC, 1996 and the Law on Banking 
and  Financial  Institutions,  1999.  Under  subprogram  1,  the  NBC  organized  workshops  in 
coordination with the MEF, Ministry of Commerce (MOC), SECC, and stakeholders to identify 
which existing laws have overlapping or conflicting provisions. Under subprogram 2, the NBC 
will update these two laws in consultation with the MEF, MOC, and SECC and incorporate the 
recommendations of the Financial Sector Assessment Program, 2010. 
 
14.  Bank supervision capacity and financial stability. As part of efforts to strengthen 
prudential supervision under subprogram 1, the NBC has developed a framework for assessing 
finance sector risks and issued supervisory guidelines to banks, adopted a road map toward 
improving compliance with core Basel principles for effective bank supervision, and reinforced 
coordination  between  the  NBC’s  Supervision  Department  and  the  Cambodian  Financial 
Intelligence Unit (CAFIU) to enforce reporting by banks. Subprogram 2 will support (i) the NBC’s 
efforts to strengthen cooperation among local finance sector regulators and with supervision 
authorities in countries that have subsidiary banks licensed in Cambodia, (ii) its requirement that 
banks  involved  in  nonbank  activities  provide  consolidated financial  statements,  and (iii)  its 
implementation of key actions toward full compliance with core Basel principles for effective 
bank supervision. 
 
15.  Prudential supervision and regulations for microfinance institutions. The NBC has 
made significant progress in building the regulatory framework for licensing and supervising 
registered MFIs. To improve financial reporting by MFIs, the NBC recently required them to pilot 
test a microfinance information system that electronically transmits MFIs’ financial reports to the

5 
NBC. Under subprogram 1, the NBC fully implemented the microfinance information system and 
ensured that all licensed MFIs complied with reporting requirements, to enhance the quality of 
off-site supervision reports. During subprogram 2, the NBC will continue to develop on-site 
supervision methodologies for effectively supervising microfinance. 
 
16.  Strong  legal  foundation  to  support  financial  and  commercial  transactions.             
A comprehensive legal framework for commerce and finance must be developed, updated, and 
implemented to support Cambodia’s financial and commercial activities. Under subprogram 1, 
the MEF, MOC, Ministry of Justice, and NBC jointly reviewed potential conflicts or overlaps 
between existing laws and agreed on necessary revisions. Further, the MOC reviewed the 
utilization of the on-line secured transactions registry. Under subprogram 2, the MEF will submit 
the draft financial trust law to the Council of Ministers, and the new insurance law to the National 
Assembly. Further, the MOC will obtain guidance from the Council of Ministers on the approach 
for setting up commercial courts and organize workshops to help increase the utilization of the 
online secured transactions registry. Activities toward the adoption and implementation of these 
laws will continue under subprogram 3. 
 
2.  Confidence and Financial Intermediation Improved 
17.  Modern payments, clearance, and settlement system. Modernizing the payments, 
clearance,  and  settlement  system  will  continue.  Under  subprogram  1,  the  NBC  held 
comprehensive consultations toward preparing a draft law on the national payments system, 
which  has  been  reviewed  by  its  management.  Further,  to  ensure  that  the  settlement  and 
transfer of securities are carried out simultaneously, the SECC has accredited three commercial 
banks as cash settlement agents for securities transactions. During subprogram 2, the NBC will 
submit the draft law on the national payments system to the Council of Ministers; commission 
the “full solution” phase of the national payments, clearance, and settlement system to facilitate 
the timely clearance and settlement of checks nationwide; and procure the shared switch for 
electronic payments and settlement. Further, the MOC will update the draft e-commerce law in 
close consultation with NBC. 
 
18.  Consumer  access  to  credit,  customer  protection,  and  market  confidence.            
The orderly development and growth of the finance sector to provide wider, more affordable and 
efficient consumer access requires knowledgeable customers and reliable information from 
providers of financial services. Under subprogram 1, the NBC issued regulations covering the 
operations of the credit bureau of Cambodia to enhance banks’ and MFIs’ compliance with 
reporting  requirements.  During  subprogram  2,  the  NBC  will  assist  the  incorporation  and 
registration of the privately owned credit bureau. Further, the NBC will, in coordination with the 
Cambodian Microfinance Association, organize a study of over-indebtedness and disseminate 
the results to stakeholders. 
 
19.  Interbank and government securities markets. The development of the interbank and 
money markets to facilitate the short-term liquidity needs of commercial banks will continue.       
In the absence of traded government securities, the NBC has launched negotiable certificates of 
deposit,  which  will  be  used  as  collateral  for  short-term  interbank  borrowing.  Under 
subprogram 1, the NBC encouraged the operation of the interbank market using negotiable 
certificates of deposit.  During subprogram 2, the MEF will develop capacity, consider the timing 
for issuance of Treasury bills in riel based on a predetermined borrowing program, and establish 
a system for accrediting primary market dealers of government securities, in cooperation with 
the NBC.

6 
20.  Domestic securities market. The development of primary and secondary markets for 
equity  securities  will  help  domestic  corporations  to  access  funds  directly  from  investors.          
The legal framework for developing a securities market was established during the second 
program. Under subprogram 1, the SECC approved the listing rules and established the support 
infrastructure for a securities market, registered and officially launched the Cambodia Securities 
Exchange, designed educational materials, and undertook a campaign to educate investors and 
build public awareness across the country. During subprogram 2, the SECC will draft a sub-
decree on bankruptcy matters related to the securities market; conduct self-assessment to 
confirm that securities market operations conform with International Organization of Securities 
Commission core principles; examine the licensing and accreditation of all securities market 
participants, including fit and proper tests; establish a customer complaints center in the SECC; 
and develop and implement a capacity-building plan for its staff. 
 
3.  Good Governance Promoted 
21.  International initiatives on anti-money laundering and combating the financing of 
terrorism. The second program commenced activities to implement anti-money laundering and 
combating  the  financing  of  terrorism  (AML/CFT)  in  Cambodia,  to  support  international 
deterrence efforts and standard governance principles and build market confidence. Under 
subprogram 1, the CAFIU addressed the Financial Action Task Force 40+9 recommendations 
following the Mutual Evaluation Report of 2011 and strengthened cooperation with the financial 
intelligence  units  of  neighboring  countries  and  related  international  organizations.  During 
subprogram 2, the CAFIU will assess the risk facing NBC-supervised institutions and other 
market institutions regarding AML/CFT, in coordination with the SECC; develop a national risk-
assessment framework and strategic implementation plan; and conduct workshops to raise 
awareness of AML/CFT among casinos, nonprofit organizations, and realtors. 
 
22.  Corporate governance and transparency in the finance sector. To build consumer 
confidence in the sector, formal finance institutions have to be more transparent in how they 
conduct business and consistently implement good governance practices. Under subprogram 1, 
the SECC developed a framework for implementing a code of corporate governance practices 
for listed companies. During subprogram 2, the NBC will require banks and MFIs to disclose 
loan terms and conditions according to a uniform framework that will help inform and protect 
clients,  as  well  as  develop  a  program  to  align  accounting  and  prudential  standards  with 
international financial reporting standards. Further, the SECC will implement a code of corporate 
governance practices for listed companies. 
 
23.  Commercial  dispute  resolution  mechanism.  Work  toward  establishing  a  national 
arbitration  center  commenced  during  the  second  program.  In  2011,  two  sets  of  qualifying 
examinations were held in March and August for the 54 selected arbitrators who, upon passing 
the examinations, will be registered as qualified arbitrators. Under subprogram 1, the MOC 
arranged for the registration of qualified arbitrators and organized the first meeting of members. 
During subprogram 2, the MOC will arrange the election of the first board of directors to run the 
national arbitration center and officially establish and help operationalize the national arbitration 
center. 
 
24.  Development of the accounting and auditing profession.  To strengthen and expand 
accounting  and  auditing  capacity,  the  MEF  introduced,  during  the  second  program,  a 
government-funded  scholarship  to  enable  70 recipients  annually to  study  toward  becoming 
members of the Kampuchea Institute of Certified Public Accountants and Auditors. Although 
results have improved since the first 3 years, some challenges remained for the MEF to attend

7 
to, including the formulation of course materials covering Cambodian taxation laws, instead of 
United Kingdom laws. Under subprogram 1, the MEF provided 35 certified public accountants 
and 35 certified accounting technician scholarships. Selection was on merit, and the MEF will 
continue to financially support scholarship holders. During subprogram 2, the MEF will update 
the Accounting and Auditing Law to reflect international developments and submit it to the 
Council of Ministers. The MEF will continue providing financial support to the train-the-trainers 
project, as these trainers will implement a standardized curriculum at 10 selected universities 
based on international financial reporting standards. 
 
4.  Finance Sector Efficiency Enhanced 
25.  Updated and modernized business registration system. The MOC corporate registry 
needs to be reevaluated and expanded to improve the national database of corporate entities 
and make corporate information more accessible to investors, lenders, and the general public. 
Under subprogram 1, the MOC reviewed current systems to ensure all commercial enterprises 
are registered and will identify areas for improvement. During subprogram 2, the MOC will 
consolidate the systems of company registration and company data storage for regulatory 
purposes and to improve public access to this information. 
 
D.  Development Financing Needs 
26.  A  total  of  $45  million  equivalent  from  ADB’s  Special  Fund  resources  has  been 
programmed for the third program, which will comprise three subprograms. The size of the 
budget support program is based on development financing needs for the sector as identified 
during country programming and strategy formulation, the importance the government attaches 
to the reform program, and the estimated costs of designing and implementing the medium-term 
reform program minus estimated financial support provided by other development partners.7 
Each successive subprogram will be processed following the successful completion of the 
subprogram preceding it. The subprogram loan will be disbursed in a single tranche upon 
satisfactory  completion  of  all  subprogram  triggers  and  following  loan  effectiveness.  The 
proceeds of the program loan will be disbursed in accordance with the provisions of ADB's 
Simplification of Disbursement Procedures and Related Requirements for Program Loans.8 
 
27.  The government has requested a loan in various currencies equivalent to $15 million 
from ADB’s Special Funds resources to help finance subprogram 1 of the third program. The 
loan will have a 24-year term including a grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 1.0% per 
annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter, and such other terms and 
conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. Loan proceeds will be used to finance the full 
foreign exchange cost of items produced and procured in ADB member countries.9 ADB will 
retain the right to audit the use of the loan proceeds and to verify the accuracy of withdrawal 
application certification. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
28.  The NBC will be the executing agency, and the MEF, MOC, and SECC will be the 
implementing agencies for the third program. The finance sector steering committee and the 
TWG, as updated under regulation 393 of 21 June 2011, will oversee the implementation of the

FSDS, 2011–2020 and coordinate with the government ministries and agencies concerned.      
To ensure timely program implementation, the TWG, chaired by a senior official of the MEF and 
comprising senior officers of the MEF, MOC, NBC, SECC, and other government agencies 
concerned, will meet as needed to review progress and consider pending issues. The TWG will 
report to the steering committee, chaired by the governor of the NBC, and will propose concrete 
actions to resolve any issues that arise. A senior officer of the NBC has been appointed as 
program director for the third program and will assist ADB in coordinating day-to-day program 
implementation with the MEF, MOC, NBC, SECC, and other relevant agencies. The program 
director will be required to submit quarterly progress reports and an annual report on the 
progress of subprogram implementation and, in particular, on progress in implementing policy 
actions adopted for the third program. 
 
III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
29.  In response to the government’s request, ADB has prepared TA to support MEF, MOC, 
NBC, and SECC implementation of key policy triggers of subprogram 2, as well as provide the 
government with timely policy advice on demand. The TA is estimated to cost $1.25 million 
equivalent, of which ADB will provide $1.1 million as a grant ($0.8 million from the Technical 
Assistance Special Fund and $0.3 million from the Cooperation Fund for Regional Trade and 
Financial Security Initiative), and the MEF, MOC, NBC, and SECC will provide the remaining 
$0.15  million  equivalent  in  the  form  of  office  space,  counterpart  staff,  and  other  support 
facilities.10 A total of 46 person-months of consulting inputs are required, 38 international and 8 
national.  Experience  in  Cambodia  has  shown  firms  to  be  more  expensive  than  individual 
consultants and unsuccessful in recruiting the right mix of consultants, especially when the 
project requires a diverse mix of expertise. The diverse nature of expertise required, with each 
individual consultant reporting to a designated implementing agency to deliver specific and 
independent  outputs,  calls  for  recruiting  individual  consultants.  ADB  will  engage  individual 
consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended 
from time to time), using competitive selection. The NBC will be the executing agency of the TA, 
and the MEF, MOC, and SECC will be the implementing agencies. 
 
IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Economic and Financial 
30.  The third program will generate economic gains through the successful implementation 
of medium-term policy actions. The estimated benefits of the program far exceed the loan 
amount. ADB estimates the potential annual economic benefits of the cluster program at $125 
million, or 1.0% of GDP, highlighting the importance of finance sector reforms to the economy.11 
The estimated costs of policy implementation to the government, statutory agencies, banks, and 
financial institutions are conservatively estimated at $59.0 million (compared with $45.0 million 
equivalent for the third program, of which $15.0 million is for subprogram 1). These include 
investment,  administrative,  enforcement,  and  fiscal  costs  to  the  government  toward 
implementing  and  enforcing  the  reforms,  estimated  at  a  minimum  of  $31.5  million.  The 
estimated  policy  implementation  costs  include  investment,  administrative,  and  increased 
business  costs  borne  by  banks  and  financial  institutions  in  complying  with  the  reforms, 
estimated at a minimum of $27.5 million.

B.  Governance 
31.  The country’s public financial management systems were assessed to better understand 
fiduciary risks and determine appropriate fiduciary arrangements for the third program. The 
government continues to emphasize strengthening the public financial management system, 
internal  control  systems,  and  the  functions  of  the  National  Audit  Authority,12 which  have 
mitigated the fiduciary risk of the public financial management system as a whole.13 Satisfactory 
progress has been noted in fiscal revenue collection, with greater use of the banking system to 
streamline revenue collection and payment processes. Subprogram 1 includes measures to (i) 
improve the management information system and reporting standards within the NBC, banks, 
insurance firms, and MFIs; (ii) promote transparency in the information released by banks, 
MFIs, insurance firms, and listed companies; (iii) support the operation of the credit bureau of 
Cambodia; and (iv) strengthen the enforcement of AML/CFT regulations.  
 
32.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  the  NBC.  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good  governance, 
accountability,  and  transparency,  the  government  will  institute,  maintain,  and  comply  with 
internal  procedures  and  controls  following  international  best  practices  for  the  purpose  of 
preventing corruption, money laundering, or the financing of terrorism and covenant with ADB to 
refrain from engaging in such activities. 
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
33.  The third program is a general intervention to support sustainable economic growth and 
is expected to reduce poverty indirectly.14 Further, finance sector development extends the 
reach of affordable formal financial services for the poor and rural microenterprises and so 
directly  reduces  poverty. While  implementing  finance  sector  reforms  based  on  competitive 
market principles has been gender neutral, improvements to the finance sector climate have 
encouraged banks and microfinance institutions to open branches in rural areas and introduce 
products and services that are more accessible to women. The NBC reported that lending by 
microfinance institutions to women increased from 21% of loans in 2002 to 76% in 2006 and 
81% in June 2011. Females held 68% of deposits in June 2011, and 27% of employees in the 
MFI subsector were female. These results show that subprogram 1 has had gender benefits. 
 
D.  Safeguards 
34.  As the third program will not entail any involuntary resettlement or negatively affect 
indigenous people or the environment, it is category C for involuntary resettlement, impact on 
indigenous people, and impact on the environment. 
 
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
35.  The third program assumes continuing political stability and macroeconomic recovery 
from the global economic downturn over the medium term. Major risks and mitigating measures

V.  ASSURANCES 
36.  The  government  and  the  NBC  have  assured  ADB  that  implementation  of  the  third 
program shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption 
measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as 
described in detail in the loan document. In addition, the government has given the following 
specific assurances, which will be incorporated into the loan agreement. The government will      
(i) implement the policy triggers in accordance with the schedule of policy reforms as described 
in the development policy letter (Appendix 3) and contained in the policy matrix (Appendix 4), as 
well as ensure the sustainability of the reforms beyond the subprogram 1 period; (ii) continue 
regular  and  timely  policy  dialogue  with  ADB  on  macroeconomic  policies  and  constraints;          
(iii) keep ADB informed of policy discussions with other multilateral and bilateral agencies that 
have implications for the implementation of subprogram 1, the third program, and the post-
program partnership framework; and (iv) provide ADB with opportunities to comment on any 
policy proposals. The government will take ADB’s views into consideration before finalizing and 
implementing any such proposals. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
37.  I am satisfied that the proposed programmatic approach and policy-based loan would 
comply with the Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend 
that the Board approve 
 
(i)  the programmatic approach for the Third Financial Sector Program; and 
 
(ii)  the loan of SDR9,571,000 to the Kingdom of Cambodia for subprogram 1 of the 
Third Financial Sector Program, from ADB’s Special Funds Resources with an 
interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% 
per annum thereafter; a term of 24 years, including a grace period of 8 years; 
and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with 
those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the Board.
